section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Juan Felipe Herrera, illustrated by Lauren Castillo
section-block.rac_book_summary: As a young boy growing up on farms in California, Juan uses his imagination as he explores nature and helps with chores. Later, his imagination helps him learn English and become an important poet.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Show children two words and have them put the words together and name the compound word. Use class + room; hand + ful; and side + walk.
Sing or say “Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star.” Invite children to join you in clapping in rhythm. Explain that poems have rhythm, but that they don’t always rhyme.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera. The narrative in this book is written as a poem.
Pablo loves poems. He is especially excited to read this one after peeking at the pictures!
I have a question I want you to think about with Pablo. We can try to answer it together. Ready?
What does Juan like to do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When we first see Juan, he is a boy. What does he like to do?
Adiós means “goodbye” in Spanish. Let’s say “adiós.”
What word do you hear at the end of every page?
Juan writes as he walks home from school. What might you write about after school?
Juan reads his poem to a big crowd.
What do you think happens after the crowd hears his beautiful words?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What does Juan like to do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Juan likes to go to school.
Juan likes to write stories and poems.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences describing where Juan grows up.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Juan like to write stories and poems?
Juan likes to write stories and p _____ (poems).
Juan likes to write stories and poems.
What does Juan use when he writes?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Several compound words appear in Imagine. Enrich children’s vocabulary by pointing out compound words like farmworkers (page 6), classroom (page 16), and sidewalk (page 25). Then, provide common words (such as fire, snow, air) and have children think of compound words that include them (firefighter, snowflake, airplane).

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Self-Awareness
section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that learning to do something new can be hard. Learning to do something well takes practice. When we learn to do something new, or get better at doing something, we feel proud of ourselves.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and notice how Juan learns to do new things. Remember, Juan Felipe Herrera wrote this narrative poem about himself.
Clifford likes to learn new things! He knows how to do some things, but he needs to practice to get better. He wants to find out how Juan learns to do new things.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about how Juan feels as he learns to do new things.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Juan says to “imagine what you could do.”
What can you imagine you would do if you were sitting outside under the stars and birds like Juan in this picture? How would you feel?
Juan practices spelling words in English. What are some things we have practiced in school? (MB)
What does Juan do for the first time in front of the class? Why should he be proud of himself? (MB)
Do you think Juan feels proud when he reads his poetry book out loud? Imagine you are reading in front of a big crowd. How would you feel? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Help children become aware of their strengths and give them an opportunity to express pride. Invite children to choose a center to work and create something there. When children have completed their creations, invite them to share them with the class and explain how they made their creations. Encourage children to express pride. (MB)
Ask children to share a time they learned to do something new. Transcribe their speech as they draw their story. Offer reinforcement of their confidence.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As children get ready for kindergarten, they will benefit from their teacher’s guidance in terms of recognizing their abilities and limitations. Doing so in a structured environment will allow them to express pride in their abilities and begin to eliminate limitations without adding stress. (Parenttoolkit.com/Self-Awareness.)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that Spanish is Juan’s home language. He learns English at school. Some words, like family and familia, are similar in English and Spanish. Say them aloud.
Show the U.S. flag and the flag for your home state. Invite two children to hold the flags. Play lively music and invite everyone to march in a “flag parade.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera. Growing up, Juan speaks Spanish with his family. He learns English when he goes to school.
Pablo is excited to reread this narrative. He thinks that learning to speak a new language is exciting!
Keep in mind this question as we reread today:
What happens after Juan learns English?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Juan whispered to the flowers’ fuzzy faces.
Use your imagination. What do you think he whispered?
Juan waves adios when his family leaves their village. How do you think Juan feels about leaving his amiguitos (friends)?
Juan calls his mother “Mamá” and his father “Papi.” What do you call your father and mother?
When Juan starts school, he doesn’t know how to read or speak English. What is something you didn’t know when you started school? (MB)
Juan reads his poetry book aloud in front of his familia and many more. What do you think familia means in English?
Did you think about this question while we reread our book:
What happens after Juan learns English?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible answers:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He reads his poems in English.

section.rac_body-text: Allow children to take turns writing answers to the questions on the board. Encourage conversation connecting English and Spanish.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Juan sing to the children at school?
Juan s______ (sings) to the children at school.
Juan sings to the children at school.
How can learning words in another language help you make a new friend?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Multilingual learners may enjoy adding to the discussion of cognates by sharing similarities between their native language and English. Explain that while cognates make it easier to talk to friends, we can also use nonverbal methods. Give examples of common nonverbal communications, such as waving hello and nodding in agreement.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: Praise children for all their accomplishments this year. Talk about the many new things they learned to do and the new friends they made.
Invite children to share something that they learned to do this year. Ask what was hard, what they got better at doing, and what makes them feel proud.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We are going to read an informational poster called I Want To . . . Let’s talk about the things you want to do!
Pablo is proud of you. You’ve learned a lot together! He wants to know what you’ll do next!
Both Imagine and I Want To . . . are about trying and learning to do new things. Let’s find connections between them!
As we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas, let’s think about the concept question:
We’re ready. What’s next?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Use the following prompts to discuss the poster and make connections to the book. Read “I want to” before each heading.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the child tying their shoes? What is something that you want to learn how to do?
In Imagine, Juan learns to speak English. What else does he learn to do?
What other things can you drive when you pretend?
What would you use to make colorful art?
Do you ever pretend to be a doctor? What job would you like to have when you grow up?
Let’s count and see how many different things we talked about on this poster.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to use their imaginations and play “When I Grow Up.” Invite children to sit in a circle. Have them take turns telling what they want to do when they grow up and showing it with an action. Then have everyone follow. For example, “I want to be a baseball player.” The child stands and bats at a ball.
Provide a writing prompt about what we learned this year and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When teachers display children’s work, children feel that it—and they—have value. When you have created the poem in the Extended Play activity, read it aloud and have children point out the words they added. Display the poem on the wall or in the hall for everyone to see. Displaying work also teaches children that hard work has value.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 4: Dream Big

section-block.rac_body-text: As you reread Imagine, use Equity Sticks to choose children to act out what you read. Acting out a read-aloud book adds a physical element that engages children and allows another level of learning. Have children draw and write in response. Allow them to share their ideas.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to reread the narrative Imagine by Juan Felipe Herrera. Juan uses his imagination as he explores nature, then later when he writes songs and stories.
Pablo uses his imagination, too. He wants to know what’s in your imaginations!
You’ve had time to think about this poem, so let’s share some of your thoughts today. As we reread it, keep in mind your answer to the guiding question:
How do you use your imagination?

section.rac_body-text: Retell and reenact the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Juan uses his imagination when he is in nature. How do you use your imagination when you are outdoors?
Juan goes to a new school and doesn’t know anyone. Tell how you would help a new friend and welcome them to your class.
Juan “collected gooey and sticky ink pens.”
Why does he collect pens? What do you like to collect?
Juan turned his poem into a song. Say something. Now sing it!
Close your eyes. Imagine you wrote a book and you’re going to share it. What is it about?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to think about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do you use your imagination?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick two or three children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I use my imagination when I play outside.
I use my imagination when I play with friends.
I use my imagination to write stories.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about something new that they have learned to do this year. Offer praise for all of their accomplishments.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you use your imagination to write stories?
I use my imagination to write st________ (stories).
I use my imagination to write stories.
What is something you imagine you will do when you grow up?

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: The Importance of Poetry
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Poetry can open worlds to young children, and help them develop cognitively. This poem follows a pattern: each page starts with if and ends with imagine. Understanding patterns will lead to better sequencing ability, which promotes the brain’s ability to process and remember information.
